MINUTE ENTRY for proceedings held before Judge Marsha J. Pechman- Dep Clerk: Grant Cogswell; Pla Counsel: Christopher Carney, Kimberly Mosolf; Def Counsel: Nicholas Williamson, Jes Erickson, Marko Pavela; CR: Nancy Bauer; Time of Hearing: 1:00PM; Status Conference via ZoomGov held on 1/10/2022. Also present for the hearing are Don Clintsman, Kathy Crane, Keri Waterland, Thomas Kinlen, Jilma Meneses, Danna Mauch, Kevin Bovenkamp, Michael Bradley, Teesha Kirschbaum, Amber Leaders, and Sjan Talbot. The Court discussed the following issues with the parties: Performance issues of in-patient admission for competency services, timeliness of in-custody jail evaluations and difficulties during COVID-19, plans to address impacts of vaccines for staff and patients, crisis intervention training with law enforcement agencies, the Governor's Supplemental Budget regarding residential services, outpatient competency restoration services, the State's plan to prioritize Trueblood class members, and the impact of Omicron on DSHS programs. Dr. Danna Mauch, Dr. Thomas Kinlen, Sjan Talbot, Amber Leaders, and Dr. Deb Pinals address the court. The Courtroom Deputy will schedule the next status conference with the parties. (GC) (Entered: 01/11/2022)

The Court hears from Dr. Mauch and the parties regarding the status of Defendants' compliance with the wait time benchmarks and other requirements previously set by the Court. Defendants' response to Plaintiffs' motion for contempt is due 10 days after 5/27/2016 and any reply is due 5 days after that. Plaintiffs' contempt motion (Dkt. No. 240) is renoted to 6/10/2016. The parties have one week to notify the Court about which witnesses they wish to call for the contempt hearing, about whether they will call the Court Monitor or her experts, and about how much time will be needed for the hearing. Plaintiffs have one week to let opposing counsel and the Court know if they intend to go any further in the 9th Circuit with respect to its opinion on the seven day requirement for competency evaluations. If they do not, Plaintiffs shall then begin the briefing process in this Court by filing an opening brief, to be briefed and noted on the motion calendar as a summary judgment motion. Defendants have one week to advise the Court on their positions and preferences regarding remand of the attorney's fees appeal.(RM) (Entered: 05/12/2016)

MINUTE ENTRY for proceedings held before Judge Marsha J. Pechman- Dep Clerk: Grant Cogswell; Pla Counsel: Christopher Carney, Kimberly Mosolf; Def Counsel: Daniel Judge, Anthony Vaupel, Travis Kuhns; CR: Marci Chatelain; Time of Hearing: 11:00AM; Courtroom: Zoom;Status Conference held on 11/9/2023. The Court holds the quarterly status conference with the parties. Also present at the hearing are: Danna Mauch, Andrew Phillips, Amnon Schoenfeld, Kathy Crane, Kevin Bovenkamp, Tom Kinlen, Teesha Kirschbaum, Amber Leaders, and Debra Pinals. The Court discusses Dr. Kinlen's declaration, an update on Cascade Behavioral Health Hospital (n/k/a Olympic Heritage Behavioral Health), update on bed capacity for Class Members, current litigation by the Counties, pending appeals, the Fines Distribution Plan and Motion for Modified Payment Schedule, increase in in-jail competency evaluation orders, and the spending on contracted staff. The Court also hears updates from Dr. Danna Mauch. The Court will issue a written order with findings made on the record at today's hearing. The Courtroom Deputy will be in contact with the parties to set the next status conference. (GC) (Entered: 11/09/2023)

MANDATE/ORDER OF USCA (23-2761) as to 1058 Notice of Appeal filed by Western State Hospital, Brian Waiblinger, Ron Adler, Dorothy Sawyer, Kevin W Quigley, Washington State Department of Social and Health Services, Eastern State Hospital. Pursuant to the stipulation of the parties, this appeal is dismissed without prejudice to its reinstatement in the event that the United States District Court declines to approve the parties' settlement by denying a Motion to Approve Settlement. Appellant must file a motion to reinstate the appeal with this court and served on the other parties and the Circuit Mediator within twenty-eight (28) days of an order by the United States District Court denying a motion to approve the parties' settlement. In the absence of the appellant's filing a timely motion for reinstatement, each party shall bear its own fees and costs on appeal. A copy of this order shall serve as the mandate of this court. DISMISSED. (RE) (Entered: 05/28/2024)

case_data.name: Trueblood v. Wash. Dep't of Social and Hlth Svc
case_data.summary: (This summary is temporary, while we research the case.) This case challenged the length of time individuals with mental disabilities spend in jail awaiting court-ordered competency evaluation and restoration services. The ACLU of Washington, Disability Rights Washington, the Public Defender Association, and private counsel brought this class-action lawsuit against the Washington State Department of Social and Health Services (“DSHS”), alleging that they failed to complete competency evaluation and restoration services for individuals in jails within the seven-day target as required by state law.

documents.text:
Case 2:14-cv-01178-MJP   Document 1   Filed 08/04/14   Page 1 of 18

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT

FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON 
11 
 
12  Cassie Cordell Trueblood, next friend of   
Ara Badayos, an incapacitated person;   
13  The Snohomish County Public Defender  No. 
Association, a non-profit corporation;   
14     
Plaintiffs,    COMPLAINT 
15  v.   
   
16  The Washington State Department of  BENCH TRIAL DEMANDED 
Social and Human Services; Western   
17  State Hospital; Kevin W. Quigley, 
Secretary of the Department of Social 
18  and Human Services, in his personal and 
official capacity; Ron Alder, Chief 
19  Executive Officer of Western State 
Hospital, in his personal and official 
20  capacity; Dr. Brian Waiblinger, Medical 
Director of Western State Hospital, in his 
21  personal and official capacity; 
 
22  Defendants. 
 
23 
   
24 
25 
26 
 
27  COMPLAINT - PAGE 1  Braden Cyrus Pence 
Snohomish County Public Defender Association 
28  2722 Colby Avenue, Suite 200 
  Everett,WA 98201 
 

Case 2:14-cv-01178-MJP   Document 1   Filed 08/04/14   Page 2 of 18
 
 
1  INTRODUCTION 
2  1.  This is a civil action seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against 
3  Defendants for allowing legally incompetent criminal defendants (hereinafter patients) 
4  to languish for months in county jails rather than promptly transporting them to a state-run 
5  mental health treatment facility for competency restoration treatment as required by court 
6  orders, state statutes, and the constitutions of the United States and Washington State.  
7  2.  Because of Defendants acts and omissions, Ms. Ara Badayos has been 
8  confined for the past 33 days (as of August 4) in solitary confinement in Snohomish 
9  County Jail (without any of the legally and medically necessary treatment) rather than at 
10  Western State Hospital (WSH) or an analogous facility where she would have spent the 
11  same period of time receiving professional care.  
12  3.  The maximum allowable time for Defendants to attempt restoration for Ms. 
13  Badayos is 45 days.  
14  4.  Defendants official position (as indicated in sworn testimony and legal 
15  filings at various Show Cause hearings in the underlying criminal actions) is that the 45 
16  day period does not begin until Ms. Badayos is transported to WSH, and that there is no 
17  timeline whatsoever for transporting her.  
18  5.  Thus, Defendants sincerely believe that there is no deadline whatsoever 
19  for transporting Ms. Badayos, and that she could lawfully be held indefinitely.  
20  6.  Plaintiffs, who are advocates for Ms. Badayos and similarly situated 
21  persons, have attempted to obtain Defendants compliance with the law by repeatedly 
22  filing motions in the state trial court.  
23  7.  The state trial courts, in piecemeal fashion, occasionally order Defendants 
24  to transport these patients and rarely dismiss the criminal actions for governmental 
25  mismanagement, but have declined to issue a general order requiring Defendants to 
26   
2 - COMPLAINT 
27 
28 
 

Case 2:14-cv-01178-MJP   Document 1   Filed 08/04/14   Page 3 of 18
 
 
1  transport competency restoration patients within a specific time period.  
2  8.  The most-recent information (dated August 1) from Defendants admit that 
3  (in addition to Ms. Badayos) approximately 100 other competency restoration patients 
4  are waiting in county jails to be transported to WSH; and that the average wait-time for 
5  each of these persons is 51 days (just under two months). See Exhibit 3 to Declaration of 
6  Trueblood at para. 3. 
7  9.  This inhumane treatment of mentally ill individuals is an ongoing crisis. 
8  Without immediate intervention, Ms. Badayos and at least 100 other similarly situated 
9  persons will continue to be unlawfully and indefinitely held in harmful circumstances and 
10  without legally and medically necessary treatment.   
11  JURISDICTION 
12  10.  This Court has federal question jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. 1331 and 
13  1343 because this is an action arising under the Fifth, Sixth, Eighth, and Fourteenth 
14  amendments to the United States Constitution.  
15  11.  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C.  1367(a), this Court has supplemental jurisdiction 
16  over related claims arising under state law, namely sections Three, Ten, Twelve, 
17  Fourteen, and Twenty Two of the Washington State Constitution, and a variety of 
18  Washington State statutes. 
19  12.  The Court has jurisdiction to award declaratory and injunctive relief 
20  pursuant to 42 U.S.C. 1983. 
21  13.  Venue is appropriate in this Court under 28 U.S.C. 1391(b)(2) because the 
22  events giving rise to this complaint occurred in Snohomish County in the Western District 
23  of Washington. 
24  PARTIES 
25  THE PLAINTIFFS 
26   
3 - COMPLAINT 
27 
28 
 

Case 2:14-cv-01178-MJP   Document 1   Filed 08/04/14   Page 4 of 18
 
 
1  14.  Ms. Ara Badayos is a 27year-old U.S. citizen domiciled in Washington 
2  State. Though she is the real party in interest, she lacks capacity to stand trial due to 
3  severe mental illness and cannot serve as Plaintiff in this action. She has no legal

5  STANDING 
6  25.  SCPDA has standing to sue on its own behalf, for injuries suffered as a result 
7  of Defendants' practice of delay in admitting criminal defendants represented by SCPDA to 
8  WSH for needed restorative mental health treatment. SCPDA will demonstrate that its 
9  ability to represent its clients' interests is being impaired by Defendants' refusal to accept 
10  custody, and that it is expending additional resources to effectively represent such clients 
11  and to advocate for a just and fair criminal justice system. On that basis, this Court should 
12  find that SCPDA has organizational standing. See Oregon v. Mink, 322 F.3d 1101, 
13  1108-09 (9th Cir. 2002); Havens Realty Corp. v. Coleman, 455 U.S. 368, 379 (1982).
